task.title: Cross-referencing content, knowledge management implications of managing section numbering and other kinds of sequential numbering
task.shortdesc: Most policy and procedure documents are extensively numbered. This provides for simple cross-referencing, but creates a massive overhead for maintainability of the whole document and, particularly, reuse of the smaller parts in other related documents. Without numbering, or where final numbering isn't going to be available to you as an author, focus on the names of elements you will refer to and reference those.

section.p: There is an obvious cost in ease of reference for particular sections. This might cause some difficulty with claiming compliance with particular sections.
There seems to be no real reason why DITA processing tools could not provide optional numbering on the output, but this doesn't seem to be a priority.

section.title: Refer to cross-referenced tables and figures by their name
Give tables and figures useful, long, unique names
What to conref
section.p: You can conref whole section elements. This probably isn't te canonical way of using conrefs, because the computer documentation tradition seems to require much more of the alteration of sentence and meaning rather than pulling whole paragraphs across.
For standards, this mechanism allows simple and predictable transclusion for smallish packets of text, with might or might not have titles.
